Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Tests of parallel divergence processes in montane plants: links between population differentiation and species diversity patterns
Award.AbstractNarration:
How did the cyclical advance and retreat of glaciers affect biodiversity within mountainous regions? How do environmental gradients and geography influence the current structure of diversity within species across their ranges? Researchers will address these questions by utilizing hundreds of DNA sequences from six closely related plant species native to the mountains of western North America. Analytical modeling techniques will allow them to determine if speciation events occurred uniformly among pairs of sister species or if they occurred under a variety of different scenarios. Subsequently, researchers will determine if glaciations that dramatically altered montane landscapes and suitable habitat during the Pleistocene Epoch (from 2,600,000 to 20,000 years ago) impacted species? distributions randomly or predictably. Finally, researchers will investigate if the current molecular variation within each of the species is distributed along environmental gradients (for example, the change in temperature between a valley floor and a mountaintop), by geography, or from the shifting of habitats during glaciations. Knowledge gained from these analyses will help researchers understand how biodiversity was created in the mountains. It will also help elucidate the relative importance of climatic stability versus specific environmental and geographic conditions in structuring the distribution of molecular diversity within species.

Organisms living in montane ecosystems are facing an uncertain future as climate change alters temperature and precipitation regimes. Many montane organisms will be forced to move upslope as lower elevations become warmer and drier, and organisms already restricted to the highest elevations may die off because suitable habitat will no longer exist. Knowing what environmental variables influence the distributions of plants across the landscape will allow land managers and conservationists to counteract declines in species? population sizes. This research will inform professionals about how habitat suitability will change across the landscape, and help them to determine from where to source plant material in order to have the best results for reintroduction or assisted migration efforts. In summary, the results will contribute information relevant to preserving biodiversity across montane landscapes by highlighting how individual species are sensitive to different environmental conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A range of contemporary and historical factors affect plant species in mountains. Our research investigated how glaciations during the Pleistocene, which occurred from about 2.6 million years ago to about 11,700 years ago, influenced plants at both high elevations and high latitudes. One pattern that is evident among groups of closely related species is that they are diverse in both the mountains of eastern Asia and western North America. Traditionally, this diversity is thought to have been achieved as species dispersed between continents, assisted during glacial times by an overland passage between Alaska and Siberia known as Beringia. We suggest an alternative method that may have facilitated plant diversity in mountains in which species adapted to mountains first had to adapt to habitats at higher latitudes and attain widespread distributions across multiple continents. Subsequently, during periods of glaciation, these species dispersed into mountains on continents that their ancestors previously did not occupy, only to get trapped there and diversify during subsequent climatic oscillations. 

Another important aspect of our research looked at the consequences of species' traits and life history characteristics on their responses to glaciations. Specifically, we collected a species that is adapted to wet habitats in mountains, such as seeps and wetlands, and a species adapted to dry habitats, such as ridges and slopes. We found that the wet-adapted species' genetic patterns coincided with widespread migration of populations to lower elevations and isolation during glaciations, while the dry-adapted species' genetic patterns reflected populations that remained tied together throughout glacial periods. The pattern in the dry-adapted species indicates that populations may have persisted at higher elevations on ridges and slopes. These findings are significant because researchers currently assume that species within communities are similarly affected by large disturbances. Furthermore, in terms of glaciations, little evidence has been collected that species were able to persist at higher elevations in mountains. On the contrary, we show that species may have very individualistic responses based on their specific traits (and that species could indeed persist at high elevations). These findings are not only important to help refine research into the impact of historical events on species and communities, but also to the present-day management and conservation efforts that focus on species that are declining due to anthropogenic factors and climate change. 

Our research resulted in several hundred plant samples that will be accessioned into the University of Michigan Herbarium and the Rocky Mountain Herbarium. These specimens represent Carex section Racemosae species endemic to mountainous regions of western North America. All molecular data generated by our research is deposited either in GenBank or the Dryad Digital Repository, and is freely available to the public. In addition, our research allowed multiple undergraduate and graduate students to gain experience in cutting edge molecular techniques. We hope that by providing students with a wide range of experiences, our research helped create interest in and support for the biological sciences.
